description: Borrowed into Middle English from Old French trenchant, the present participle of trenchier (“to cut”).

adjectives.description: trenchant (comparative more trenchant, superlative most trenchant)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Fitted to trench or cut; gutting; sharp.
examples: The trenchant blade, Toledo trusty, / For want of fighting was grown rusty, / And ate into itself, for lack / Of somebody to hew and hack.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Keen; biting; vigorously articulate and effective; severe.
